title: U.S. News: U.S. Watch
text:
By Cyberattackers

A criminal organization that recently hacked the Los Angeles public-school system released some illegally obtained data over the weekend, the district said, after the superintendent refused to pay a ransom.

Los Angeles Unified School District superintendent Albert Carvalho on Sunday didn't reveal the demands made by the criminal organization or the type of data that was released.

Mr. Carvalho said on Friday that school officials and law enforcement were aware a data release was imminent, adding that he didn't believe that giving in to blackmail would solve the problem.

"Paying ransom never guarantees the full recovery of data," he said. "Los Angeles Unified believes public dollars are better spent on our students rather than capitulating to a nefarious and illicit crime syndicate."

-- Ginger Adams Otis

---

NEBRASKA

Vehicle Hits Tree,

Killing Six People

Six people died after a car struck a tree in Lincoln early Sunday.

Lincoln Police said the crash was reported around 2:15 a.m. after an iPhone carried by one of the passengers detected the impact and called emergency responders automatically when the owner of the phone didn't respond.

Five men in the car died at the scene. Paramedics took a 24-year-old woman to the hospital in critical condition where she died later.

The five men who died included the 22-year-old driver. The other victims included one 21-year-old, one 23-year-old and two 22-year-olds.

-- Associated Press

---

MINNESOTA

Plane Strikes House,

Three Aboard Die

Three people aboard a small airplane died when it crashed into a house near a northern Minnesota airport, but the two people sleeping inside the home were unhurt.

Hermantown Police said the Cessna 172 plane crashed into the second floor of the home just south of the Duluth airport late Saturday, before coming to rest in the backyard.

-- Associated Press
